awd_titl_txt: Active Learning Modules to Support Problem-Based Learning: Effects on Engineering Retention and Academic Outcomes of At-Risk Students
awd_abstract_narration:
In response to the Nation's need to improve the preparation of undergraduate students so they can succeed as productive members of the future STEM workforce, this project expands and explores an instructional approach that has shown promising results in increasing the success of undergraduate engineering students in an introductory course - engineering design graphics. The overarching purpose of the project is to refine a transferable active learning framework and the associated instructional resources to promote engineering persistence, academic success, and engagement. Such an instructional approach is critical and has strong implications for student persistence in engineering degree programs. The impacts of this project will include: (a) promoting the design and development of effective STEM learning and teaching knowledge and practice; (b) broadening the implementation of effective instructional practices and innovations; (c) enhancing retention of STEM students by addressing high failure rates in introductory classes; and (d) increasing the persistence of all demographic groups in the first two years of college. 

More specifically, the project's approach will involve the use of active performance learning modules. The investigative team will explore the factors that affect program persistence in order to create a curricular approach that will improve the student experience, particularly for at-risk students, such as female students, underrepresented minorities, and first-generation college students. The instructional approach of this project will be disseminated to other two- and four-year institutions and will include recommendations for identifying at-risk students and for improving student engagement and retention. A mixed-methods design will enable the investigative team to collect and analyze information from students related to: program persistence, self-efficacy, academic success, and engagement. The project will have implications not only for effectiveness of student learning, but also for the retention of students in engineering.

por.por_cntn:
In order to increase persistence in engineering degree programs, the Active Learning Modules to Support Problem-Based Learning: Effects on Engineering Retention and Academic Outcomes of At-Risk Students project developed and evaluated online active learning modules in an introductory engineering graphics course. Persistence rates in engineering fields are lower than in other STEM and non-STEM fields. The traditional format of engineering course delivery through lectures of large populations may not be optimal for students identified as at risk of non-matriculation. Therefore, the development of engaging online active learning modules that relate course content to a real-world application can serve to improve students’ self-efficacy, academic success, and spatial ability that are all factors impacting persistence. 

Through program evaluation, significance was identified for student self-efficacy, mental rotation ability, final exam grades, and self-regulation. Identifiable differences between students enrolled in engineering design graphics at risk of non-matriculation and students not at risk were also identified in areas of self-efficacy, mental rotation ability, and final exam grades. Artifacts from the study include the online active learning module framework, an open access ebook with a print-on-demand option format of the active learning modules, as well as published articles and conference presentations communicating the impacts of applying active learning modules. 

    The online active learning modules are a combination of ten modules focussed on relating introductory engineering graphics content to real-world applications to increase understanding of basic principles. The modules were delivered to students through an online learning management software where students completed the modules anytime between classes so that course time could be used for hands-on practice versus lecturing. After the study, the modules will be freely available to the public for secondary or post-secondary levels through open access in an ebook version as well as and print-on-demand option available for the cost of printing. 

Support for the structure and delivery of the active learning modules has been made available through a number of peer-reviewed journals and communicated at several conferences. With such support, the project has provided to the public a resource of knowledge and related material for incorporating elements associated with increasing persistence, especially of underrepresented populations and students at risk of non-matriculation, in the structuring of engineering or related programs. Additionally, the study can be used in the public to further support research related to active learning modules and improving engineering persistence rates. 

This IUSE project provides, to the public, both support for an active learning modules framework as well as content that can be used in the classroom to further student success in engineering programs.


Last Modified: 08/31/2021
Modified by: Jeremy Ernst
